name: Laylat al-Qadr (Night of Power)
description: The holiest night of Ramadan, when the Qur'an was first revealed to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ. Worship on this night is considered better than a thousand months.

name: Eid al-Fitr
description: Festival marking the end of Ramadan. Muslims celebrate with prayers, charity, feasts, and community gatherings.

name: Day of Arafah
description: The day before Eid al-Adha, when pilgrims gather at Mount Arafat during Hajj. It is highly recommended for non-pilgrims to fast.

name: Eid al-Adha
description: Festival of Sacrifice, commemorating Prophet Ibrahim’s willingness to sacrifice his son for Allah. Animals are sacrificed and meat shared with the poor.

name: Islamic New Year
description: Marks the beginning of the Islamic lunar calendar year, starting with Muharram.

name: Ashura
description: A day of fasting and reflection. For Sunnis, it commemorates Prophet Musa’s deliverance from Pharaoh. For Shia Muslims, it marks the martyrdom of Imam Hussain at Karbala.

name: Mawlid al-Nabi (Prophet's Birthday)
description: Celebration of the birth of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ, observed with gatherings, recitations, and remembrance.

name: Isra and Mi'raj
description: Commemorates the miraculous night journey and ascension of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ to the heavens.

name: Shab-e-Barat
description: Known as the Night of Forgiveness. Muslims spend the night in prayer, seeking forgiveness and blessings.

name: Ramadan Begins
description: The start of the holy month of fasting, prayer, charity, and spiritual reflection.

name: Hajj Begins
description: The annual pilgrimage to Mecca, one of the five pillars of Islam, obligatory once in a lifetime for those who are able.

name: Mid-Sha'ban
description: Observed in some traditions as a night of prayer and preparation before Ramadan.
